channel.title: "For" and "Foreach" loops PHP
channel.description: Okay this might be a really stupid question but I am starting to learn PHP on CodeCademy (Which I Highly recommend) and I am starting to learn loops now in PHP. I am really confused on if their is even a difference between a "for" loop and a "foreach" loop. Is it that in a "foreach" loop that you can rename the variable or whatever? Idk but an explanation would be great for this noobie question :palm: ;D

item.title: "For" and "Foreach" loops PHP
item.dc:creator: @pure2ownage Pure_
item.description:
@pure2ownage wrote:

[code=php]$my_array = array(1, 2, 3, 4, …);

foreach ($my_array as &$val) { // you use & to give you the array value reference, to allow direct modifications to the array elements - worth reading about pointers etc
$val += 1;
}[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: "For" and "Foreach" loops PHP
item.dc:creator: @robonick8 robonick8
item.description:
@robonick8 wrote:

[quote=“SilentCJ, post:5, topic:542714”][quote author=robonick8 link=topic=661589.msg4422097#msg4422097 date=1398959717]

foreach will iterate through a given array, with each value in the array represented as the given variable in the loop.

a for loop uses three expressions. the first is generally defining all your variables. second expression is the conditional you’re checking. if this expression stays true, the loop will continue until it is false, iterating through all possible outcomes. the third expression will be your modifier. how do you want to go through the conditional?

these are probably bad explanations but hopefully you can get the difference

Thank you so much!! this helped so you are saying that a “for” with the 3 expressions are after each semicolon?

[/quote]
Exactly. However that code would only execute once (kinda pointless using a loop ), if you wanted it to execute 11 times then the ‘modifier’ would be $i++, which just increments the value of $i by 1.

Also worth mentioning that you can simulate a foreach loop with a for loop by using $i < count($array) as the condition.[/quote]

Could you give me your skype so if I have an questions you could help? I dont want to be spamming forums with constant questions all the time

Read full topic

item.title: "For" and "Foreach" loops PHP
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

[quote=“robonick8, post:3, topic:542714”][quote author=Vain_ link=topic=661589.msg4422095#msg4422095 date=1398957355]
foreach will iterate through a given array, with each value in the array represented as the given variable in the loop.

a for loop uses three expressions. the first is generally defining all your variables. second expression is the conditional you’re checking. if this expression stays true, the loop will continue until it is false, iterating through all possible outcomes. the third expression will be your modifier. how do you want to go through the conditional?

these are probably bad explanations but hopefully you can get the difference
[/quote]

Thank you so much!! this helped so you are saying that a “for” with the 3 expressions are after each semicolon?

Exactly. However that code would only execute once (kinda pointless using a loop ), if you wanted it to execute 11 times then the ‘modifier’ would be $i++, which just increments the value of $i by 1.

Also worth mentioning that you can simulate a foreach loop with a for loop by using $i < count($array) as the condition.

Read full topic

item.title: "For" and "Foreach" loops PHP
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

I don’t think I’ve ever actually used a standard for loop in PHP… foreach usually does what you want.

Read full topic
